Award.AwardTitle: Enhancing Diversity in Graduate Education: Research Results From Twenty Years of Empowering Women in Mathematics
Award.AbstractNarration:
This award supports participation in the session "EDGE (Enhancing Diversity in Graduate Education) Program: Pure and Applied Talks by Women" held at the Joint Mathematics Meetings (JMM) in San Diego, CA on Thursday January 11th from 8-10 a.m. and 1-4 p.m. The EDGE program was established in 1998 to empower women, particularly underrepresented minority women, to complete graduate degrees in mathematics and to increase the visibility of women in the mathematical sciences. Since then, hundreds of women have been involved with the EDGE program. This session will showcase mathematical contributions of women who have been affiliated with the EDGE program and will serve as a platform to strengthen the network of women mathematicians. Graduate students, postdoctoral researchers, and early career faculty will have the opportunity to interact with successful senior female mathematicians.

To commemorate twenty years since the first summer program was held in 1998, the morning session will feature invited talks by women who participated in one of the early EDGE summer programs, completed PhDs, and have gone on to lead successful careers in the mathematical sciences. The afternoon session will feature contributed talks by graduate students, postdoctoral researchers, and early career mathematicians who have also been involved in the EDGE program. More information on the 2018 Joint Mathematics Meeting can be found at: http://jointmathematicsmeetings.org/meetings/national/jmm2018/2197_program.html

POR.DRECONTENT:
The purpose of this award was to fund travel for participants of the 2018 and 2019 conference sessions titled ?20th Anniversary-The EDGE (Enhancing Diversity in Graduate Education) Program: Pure and Applied Talks by Women? and  ?The EDGE (Enhancing Diversity in Graduate Education) program: Pure and Applied talks by Women Math Warriors?, respectively, held at the JointMathematics Meetings (JMM). The goal of the sessions was to bring together female mathematicians from all mathematical disciplines to highlight the successes of women and especially women of color in math on a national stage.

The 2018 session took place in San Diego, California on January 11, 2018 and consisted of 16 invited talks by women, including 9 women of color. The 2019 session took place in Baltimore, Maryland on January 17, 2019 and consisted of 12 talks by 15 women, including 7 women of color. The broader mathematics community benefits from the sessions? goal of increasing the visibility of women and women of color in mathematics, since this visibility encourages bright young women to pursue careers in mathematics when they may otherwise be discouraged by the sense of isolation commonly reported by underrepresented groups in mathematics. This isolation stems from a lack of peers undergoing similar experiences as minorities in mathematics, as well as a lack of role models and advisors who understand the challenges specific to women and underrepresented minorities in mathematics. The EDGE session helped to address some of these unique challenges by providing a platform for discussion and by celebrating the achievements ofwomen and underrepresented minorities in mathematics.Early-career women in mathematics who attended the EDGE session heard talks by peers and mentors from a variety of mathematical and social backgrounds, and benefited from seeing role models who look like them succeeding in mathematics.

The talks covered a wide range of topics, showcasing the breadth and depth of the research done by members of the EDGE community.  The audience learned where to place robots, how nematocysts use super-fast firing to navigate, and how classification algorithms are used to understand the DNA of bacteria.  Talks in pure mathematics addressed problems in number theory, knot theory, differential geometry, algebra and analysis.  EDGErs also described their research in math education and lessons learned in the communication of mathematics.  Some of this work is now published in the volume ? A Celebration of the EDGE Program?s Impacts on the Mathematics Community and Beyond? (Springer, 2019)

In addition, the diversity of career stages and mathematical disciplines represented at the EDGE sessions presented an opportunity for early-career women to receive professional guidance and support from a variety of mentors who may not necessarily be working in a related area of math. The session speakers and audience spanned many career stages, including graduate students, postdoctoral students, government and industry professionals, and both early-career and established professors. This allowed participants to not only exchange research ideas, but also professional and career advice. The sessions provided an opportunity for women on the job market to invite potential employers to their talks and to receive feedback from EDGE mentors. In addition, the EDGE session even inspired undergraduates in attendance at the JMM to apply for the EDGE summer program before beginning graduate studies.
